The Eastern Telegraph Company, Limited.
div.p:
This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.

STATIONS IN EGYPT: Alexandria, Cairo,
Suez, Port-Tewfik, Port-Saïd, Suakin. Head
Office. London.

div.head: Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: Berths can be definitely engaged beforehand. Plans can be seen at the Offices of the Company's Agents.

The through Steamers for Marseilles, Gibraltar, Plymouth, and London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Monday. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindisi Express Steamer leaves Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before.
The express steamer usually reaches Brindisi on Wednesday afternoon, the special train starting at 8 p.m and arriving in London at the very convenient hour of 4.56 p.m on Friday.
The combined Sea and special train fare is 22.9.11 Port Said to London via Brindisi or via Marseilles.
Passengers having paid full fare in one direction are allowed an abatement of 25 per cent on returning within 12 months.
In addition to the above regular weekly service there are sailings about twice a fortnight of 5,000 to 7,000 tons steamers to London, calling at Malta or Marseilles.
TO THE EAST:

The Mail Steamers leave Suez for Arden and Bombay every Wednesday, and for Australia and China every alternate Wednesday. A steamer leaves for Calcutta, fortnightly, and another for Japan. Passengers can embark at Port Said.
For all further information apply to the Company's Agents,
Messrs. THOS. COOK & SON (Egypt) Ltd. CAIRO.
GEORGE ROYLE, Esq. PORT-SAID.
Messrs. HABELDEN & Co. ALEXANDRIA.
F. G. DAVIDSON, Superintendent P. & O. S. N. Company in Egypt SUEZ.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 4 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MERSINE, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez weekly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for Port Badam and SUAKIN direct returning from Suakin every Wednesday noon. Every Monday at 6 p.m. a steamer leaves Suez for Jeddah continuing every other week to SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODEIDAB, ADEN. Intermediate steamers do not proceed beyond Jeddah but call at Tor, (for Sinai) El Wedj and Yambo as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company’s Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

div.head: Austrian Lloyd’s Steam Navigation
div.p: Alexandria-Brindisi-Venice-Trieste.

Weekly Express Mail Service. Steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 4 p.m. arrive Brindisi, Tuesday a.m. in time for express to Milan, Loverne, Paris, Vienna, Berlin, and London, leaving Brindisi at 7 a.m. Arrival Venice every Wednesday about 8.30 a.m. in time fro Express to Switzerland, Paris, and London, leaving Venice 2 p.m. and 11.20 p.m. Arrival Trieste every Wednesday about 3 p.m. in connection with Train de Luxe Trieste-Vienna-Ostende. Passengers reach London every Friday 4.50 p.m. Passengers from Cairo will find special through carriages and luggage-van attached every Saturday to Express leaving Cairo 9.30 a.m. and are conveyed directly to Quay alongside steamer. (Trieste-Ostende through carriage) and expresses to Italy and Germany.

div.p: One of the finest and most up-to-date Hotels in the Metropolis. Situated in Sharia Soliman Pasha, the very centre of the healthiest and most fashionable quarter. div.head: MONDAY, APRIL 2, 1906.
ALGECIRAS.
div.p: The whole civilised world will welcome the news of the happy issue of the most momentous international debate that has been convened since the Berlin Conference. A few days ago, in discussing the possible peaceful termina¬tion of the Algeciras conference, the “Morning Post” declared that it would have been a mis-fortune of the first magnitude if the affair of Morocco had led to a quarrel between any of the Great Powers. In spite of the strong na¬tional feeling which exists in each of the coun- tries principally concerned in these negotiations there is no sane and sensible man either in Germany, France, Spain, or Great Britain who really thinks that Morocco, taken on the maximum valuation, is worth a conflict be¬tween any of the Powers. Supposing its soil to be the most fertile, its climate the most bene- ficent in the world, and its mineral wealth to be inexhaustible, yet the question whether the task of bringing into its administration the beginnings of order and of giving to European residents and traders the elements of security for person and property should be

entrusted to one Power or to more, and even the question whether a settlement now made might or might not give one Power something of a special position in the country, are not worth a struggle between civilised Powers. Such a conflict would in six months destroy more wealth and absorb more human energy than Morocco could in any case reproduce in half a century, Of this all the Powers concern¬ed are firmly convinced, and the fact that they are so having been well known has made graver, from the beginning, the anxiety with which the possibility of a deadlock has been regarded. Everyone has put the question, “What’s he to Hecuba or Hecuba to him ?” and in the absence of a possible answer has sought behind the friction and delay which have attended upon diplomacy for sums profound explanation.

The great prestige with which Bismarck sur-rounded the policy of the German Empire, the presumed astuteness and profundity of German diplomacy, and the generally recognised excel¬lence of the German military and naval organi¬sation have erased most observers to imagine that Germany had some deep design. The theory weir known to be held by many officers of the German Army that Germany ought to take the first opportunity to attack France in order that she might be unable to take part in the future conflict which, these same officers imagine to be inevitable between Germany and Great Britain, lent itself to the hypothesis that the German Government was meditating an attack upon France of which the excuse was to be found in some disagreement con- cerning Morocco. The tone in which the German Government has for several years without a solitary exception alluded to its relations with Great Britain has lent colour to the same hypothesis. Even when a British Ad¬miral on a visit to a German port in the Baltic sent a message conveying his respects to the German Emperor, the Emperor’s reply was almost as frigid and as chilling to British feelings as his famous message to President Kruger. Sentiment asked what these things meant, and could only infer that they boded no good. But the German Emperor, though he is a careful student of German sentiment, and therefore as a rule carries it with him even when—perhaps especially when—he offends the sentiment of other nations, is not a senti¬mental statesman. He is always doing business, and the feelings of his own and other rations are a portion of the data upon which his calculations are based. He has not, and never has had, the idea of plunging Germany into an international conflict without knowing the reason why and without foreseeing a satis ¬-factory ending. In the case which has been during the last few months thought possible, there has been no sufficient reason why. Ger¬many was subject to no menace. Her territory, her rights, her interests were in no way threat -ened. It is just conceivable that Prince Bulow may have taken umbrage at the expression used in the Anglo-French Agreement about Morocco by which Great Britain ‘ recognised that France was entitled to a peculiar posit on in that country. But though the words used may not have been formally unexceptionable, and would, perhaps, have been better omitted, seeing that the substance was perfect¬ly conveyed by the undertaking not to obstruct the action which France might take in Morocco any objection that could be raised was merely formal, fir no one in the world doubted that Morocco and its good order was a matter of special interest to France, and no one in the world supposed that Great Britain claimed any right to dispose of anything in Morocco beyond her own rights and interests in that country.The probability is that the German Govern¬ment wished it to be understood that no such settlement as that of the future of Morocco ought to be effected without Germany’s being con¬sulted and being a consenting party. That having been made plain, and that wish having been met, the main intention of German policy in the matter has probably been fulfilled. No doubt there may be a little more behind. Bismarck and his disciples learned something from Napoleon, and Napoleon learned from his master in strategy never to make a project without two faces. It is likely enough, there- fore, that Germany, while pressing her point in regard to Morocco, has had her eye on something else as well, and that while the theory of the right of Germany to be consulted in any settlement of Morocco has been asserted the wishes of Germany in regard to the Middle East have also been kept in mind. That remains to be seen.

div.head: Local and General
div.p: Yachts.
The British S. Y. Evona arrived at Alex¬-andria on Saturday from Bombay and Pet Said, and the Honor from Messina yesterday.
Hashish Seizure.
On Saturday the Coastguards seized 15 kilos of hashish by the shore near Agame. It had evidently been thrown overboard the night before by some boat whioh was unable to land it.
Lots Turcs.
We are informed by the Imperial Ottoman Bank and the Credit Lyonnais that the gros lot of the Ottoman Railway Lottery was won on Saturday by the holder of bond No. 1,544,100.
Pyramid Illuminated.

On the occassion of the visit of the Prince end Princess of Wales to the Pyramids on Wednesday, the Pyramid of Cheops will be illuminated and the management of Mena House Hotel has prepared special dinners for those who are going out that night.
Finds at Oxyrhynchus.

The work of discovery at Oxyrhynchus during the last season has resulted in a large accumulation of material, no fewer than one hundred and seventeen boxes of papyri being brought away. Among the most interesting finds are a comedy of Philemon on which Plautus based his “Aulularia,” and a discourse on music, perhaps by Hippias of Elis. A con-¬tract dated in the fifth year of Sotu I. furnishes the oldest date yet found on a Geek papyrus. A very interesting document is a Greco- Roman calendar about BC 300, giving data as to the various deities and their festivals.
Researchers in Sinai.

The materials and discussions of Professor Flinders Petrie’s new book, ‘Researches in Sinai," which will shortly be published, are not drawn from any previous publication. They contain the first detailed account of the Egyptian remains in Sinai, the results being given in chronology, with a revision of the dates in Egyptian history according to the most recent results. The Semitic discoveries, which are entirely new, include the system of Semitic ritual and the common use of a Semitic writing in the earliest age, the conditions of climate, the route of the Exodus, the question of the numbers of the Israelites down to the monarchy, and the evidences of early docu¬ments in the Pentateuch.
Spend your Holidays at Mena,
The management of Mena House Hotel has arranged special terms for residents of Cairo, Alexandria, and country from the 10th of April to the 10th of May. [Advt.]

div.head: Egyptian Estates
div.p: Report of Directors

The following is the report of the directors of the Egyptian Estates, to be submitted to the shareholders at the first annual general meeting to be held at Winchester House. Old Broad, street, London, E C., on Wednesday, 11th inst. : — The directors herewith present the first balance sheet and profit and loss account made up to the 13th March, 1906. The company was registered on the 3rd March, 1905, but it was some months before it was able to commence operations, and the average period for which the subscribed capital has been available does not exceed six months. During the past three months 179.315 additional ordinary shares have been issued, of which 153,315 will row rank for dividend with the original capital. Five per cent, debentures have also been issued for £150 000 part of £300 0 0 created. If the issue of the remainder should be thought advisable, the available resources of the company, include-ing the reserves now created, would amount to over £800,000. The whole of the lands and properties shown in the balance sheet are car¬r-ied at cost, and on a revaluation would shows a large appreciation on the purchase price. The amount to the credit of profit and loss account is £67.177 1649d. This does not include a sum of £25,655 17s. 7d. shown in the balance sheet, but which, although ascertained profit, is only payable by instalments extending over the next 2 1/2 years, and is, therefore, not divisible profit at the present time. The directors pro-pose the payment of a dividend of 2s. per share, free of income tax upon the ordinary shares. This will absorb £40,492 2s, and will entail an appropriation of £ 0,900 to the deferred shares, which will admit of a dividend of 10s. 9d. per share being paid on these shares. The directors, in the exercise of their powers, have placed £126 071 17s. 6d. to reserve, being the amount of premiums received on shares allotted since the issue of the prospectus, against which have been written oft the whole of the preliminary expenses an 1 the expenses of the debenture issue to date, leaving a ret balance on reserve account of £10-1,090 12s. l0d. In accordance with Article 99 of the Articles of Association, the Directors are entitled to one- tenth of the profits over and above an amount sufficient to pay a dividend of 7 per cent. per annum on the ordinary shares, and £3,23 5s. 4d. will be appropriated under this head. These various amounts, deducted from the £67 177 16s. 9d. will, after due provision has been made for income tax, leave a balance of £9/89 Us. 7d. The directors wish to place upon record their high appreciation of the services rendered to the company by the managing director in Egypt, Mr. Montagu Summers, and of the able co-operation of Mr. Lang Anderson and George Nungovich Bey.

div.head: The Austrian Squadron
div.p: The Austro-Hungarian colony at Alexandria gave a magnificent fete yesterday afternoon in honour of Rear-Admiral von Jedina and the officers of the Imperial and Royal squadron now at Alexandria. The fete took place at the New Khedivial Hotel from 4 to 8 o’clock and was attended by all the leading representatives of Alexandrian society, the officers of the Ame¬rican man-of war Brooklyn, the members of the Diplomatic and Consular Corps, etc. This evening there will be a fete at the A’hambra Theatre in honour of the petty officers and sailors of the squadron On Thursday next Rear Admiral von Jedina and the officers will give a ball on board the Habsburg and the St. George.

div.head: The Royal Visit
div.p: T.R.H. at All Saints'
VISIT PAID TO THE BARRAGE

Yesterday their Royal Highnesses the Prince and Princess of Wales attended morning service at All Saints’ Church Cairo. Of coarse, the building was crowded and it was fortunate that the restoration of the north aisle had been completed or there would not have been room for the congregation. As it is, the in¬adequacy of the church accommodation is only too apparent. Three clergymen took part in the service. Rev. Thompson Barns, M. A., read the prayers, Right Rev. Bishop Morley, D.D., acting Archdeacon in Egypt, celebrated the Holy Communion, and the Very Rev. Dean Butcher preached from the 1st Lesson Exodus 8.2: ‘‘And he looked, and behold the bush burned with fire and the bush was not consumed." The Dean spoke of the scene of the vision of the Peninsula of Sinai, of which we now know much more than we ever did before, and of the symbolism of the vision itself, the fire representing, first, the discipline of trial, secondly, the comforting and enlightening effects of the Holy Spirit. He mentioned the fact that the burning bush and the text were the emblem and motto of the Church of Scot¬land. He quoted Matthew Arnold’s well-known sonnet on Marcus Aurelius: “ There were no suoccours here The aids to noble life were all within.” and contrasted this with the experience of the humblest Christian, who can always obtain through Christ—help from outside— the aid of the Holy Spirit. The hymns selected by their Royal High¬nesses were No. 260 in H A. and M., “Hark my soul," No. 438 ‘ How bright those glorious spirits shine," and 215, ‘ The Church’s one Foundation." There was an unusually large choir admirably directed by Mr. Peacock. The Earl of Cromer met the Royal party at the church door and sat with them in the Agency pew. General Bullock, C.B., Major Watson Pacha, C.M.G., D.S.O., and several members of the suite occupied the first four seats. After attending divine service their Royal Highnesses returned to Abdeen Palace, after¬wards lunching with Brig. General Bullock. In the afternoon they paid a visit to the Barrage, accompanied by H.H. the Khedive, by whose desire the gardens were closed to the public during the afternoon. Sir Wm. Garstin also accompanied their Royal High¬nesses. The party went out on the Khedive's yacht. The Nile was so rough and the wind so trying, however, that the Khedive and T. R. H., after arriving at the Barrage and inspecting the works, gardens, etc., wired to Cairo for a special train, by which the re¬turn journey was made.

div.head: The Plague.
div.p: Six cases of plague were reported from the Keneh district on Saturday, four of them terminating fatally. The Public Health Department has just issued a report on bubonic plague in Egypt from February 26 to April 1, which shows a total of 19 oases, 15 of which have proved fatal, the remainder being under treatment.

div.head: H.M.S. Perseus
div.p: Commander Marcus Rowley Hill, R.N., of H.M S. Perseus, was introduced on an official visit to Ibrahim Halim Bey, the Governor of Suez, by Mr. V. Hughes-Laferla, British Pro-Consul at Suez, on Saturday last. The Governor returned the visit on board the Perseus the same afternoon. H.M.S. Perseus is a 3rd-class twin-screw cruiser. She is returning to her station at Aden to-day.

div.head: A GALLANT RESCUE.
div.p: Yesterday morning, at about 10.30 o’clock, a Greek was walking along the lower parapet of the new quay near Fort Silsileh, when he slipped and fell into the sea. The nearest Coast- guard sentry was informed and he promptly proceeded to the spot with a life-saving apparatus. By this time the Greek had drifted oat about sixty yards from the quay wall and was too exhausted to swim to the buoy, which had been thrown out as far as possible. The sea was breaking heavily over the wall and there appeared to be little hope for the man, as although there was a small crowd of onlookers no one proffered any help. However, a Coast¬guard orderly, Ahmed Ibrahim Hamid, who was passing by, on seeing the man’s predica¬ment, called to the crowd and asked whether any of them would try to save the life of the drowning man. No one made reply, so he at once stripped and plunged into the sea. He swam out with the buoy to the Greek and assisted him alongside the quay, where he was hauled up. If this act of bravery had taken place at home the rescuer would certainly have been entitled to the medal of the Royal Humane Society. There are decorations, Medjidish and Osmanieh, for the officers, but there is none for the men in Egypt. Why should not a special Order be created for deeds of bravery? At any rate it is to be hoped that the brave coastguardeman will meet with some reward.

div.head: MILITARY TOURNAMENT
div.p: GREAT SOCIAL SUCCESS.
PRESENCE OF ROYALTY.

This year’s Military Tournament at Abbas- sieh was honoured by the presence of the Prince and Princess of Wales, and in consequence of this fact, and of the excellent management of the committee, proved a great social success. It was from every point of view a social event of the first magnitude, and we have never seen so representative a gathering so late in the Cairo season. The committee had done their work admirably throughout. The eighteen events on their programme were all attractive and often amusing. The tent pegging was de- cidedly good, the riders taking the pegs with great finish and neatness. The wrestling on horseback delighted the audience—though for other reasons than the tent pegging—and the physical drill displays, bayonet fighting and contests between various aims delighted all who watched them. But it was the social and not the athletic side of the function that made it most interesting to all who were present. Here again, the committee, after issuing a great number of invitations, had obviously made up its mind to do all in its power for the entertainment of its guests. The enclosure was therefore roped in on the S. E. side of the parade ground so that neither sun nor wind made their presence unduly felt—a boon and blessing if ever was one. A smaller en¬closure was reserved for the Ministers, the Diplomatic and Consular Corps, and for the members of the Caisse de la Dette, and next to it was the Khedivial tent. At the opposite extremity of the enclosure was the tea tent, which was always thronged and admirably managed by Mr. Wild of the Savoy Hotel. George Nungovich Bey devoted himself with skill and assiduity to the supply of the Khe-divial party and the Royal visitors. The fact that in spite of the presence of nearly 1,000 visitors the tea tent triumphantly met all demands (on a warm afternoon too) merits mention. The committee, which deserves any amount of credit for its successful organisation of the tournament, and of thanks for the hospitality extended to so many guests by its members in conjunction with the Sirdar and the officers corps of the Egyptian Army, consisted of, Miralai Matehett Bey, Miralai Palmer Bey, Kaimakam Gordon Bey, Kaimakam Stockwell Bey Kaimakam Hassan Bey Hilmy, Bimbashi Flint. Bimbasbi Betbell, Bimbashi Broadbent and Bimbashi Rome. The programme had been drawn up by Saghcologassi Ahmed Effendi Fetin. The police arrangements and traffic control were perfect and Man-field Pacha’s subordinates did wonders. The native population of Cairo was there is its thousands. A long row of harem carriages on the side of the parade-ground opposite to the enclosure testified to the interest aroused among the Turkish and Arab ladies of Cairo by the tournament and the Royal visit, and the rank and file of the Egyptian Army were out in hundreds. The Corps Diplomatique, the Ministers, and the members of the Legislative Council were present in full strength at the ceremony. The Sirdar and Lady Wingate with a strong con¬tingent of officers and officials from the Sudan were present, and among others we noticed Sir William Garstin, Lord Edward Cecil, Mr. Percy Macbell and Lady Victoria Machell. Mr. and Mrs. And Mrs. De C. Findlay, Sir John and Lady Rogers, Sir Horace Pinching, Mr. Douglas Dunlop, Mr. Dugdale and the Lady Eva Dugdale, Crookshank Pacha and Mrs. Crook shank, Mr. Webb, Sir Augustus and Lady Hemming, Miss Hemming, Gen. Bullock, Mrs. Bullock, Miss Bullock, Coles Pacha, Mrs. Coles and the Misses Coles, Mr. and Mrs. Scott Dalgleish Mr. and Mrs. Alban, the Misses Hurley, Mr. and Mrs, Rumboldt, Mr. Higgins, Mr. and Mrs. George Royle, Major Stack, Judge and Mrs. Marshall, Owen Bey, Capt. and Mrs. Failey, Mr. and Mrs. Allan Joseph, Miss Joseph, Mr. Dicey, Mr. and Mrs. Autley Friend, Mr. and Mrs. Arnold Perry, Mr. Stout, Mrs. and Miss Reid, Mr. D. Reid, Mr. J Reid, Mr. Berens, Mr. and Mrs. Huteson, Mrs. Wallich, Mr. and Miss de Bilinski, Major and Mrs. Donegan, Capt. and Mrs. Morgan, Mr. and Miss Farrell, Miss Alicia Brown, Mrs. and the Misses York, Mrs. and Miss Leverich, Mrs. and Miss Whittaker, Mr. and Mrs. Wild, Mr. and Mrs. Tatton Brown, Major and Mrs. Wynne, Mrs. and Miss Rees, Miss de Codt, Mr. and Mrs. Hogg, Mrs. Parvis, Milhem Bey Shakoor and Miss Shakoor, Judge and Mrs. Tuck, Dr. and Mrs. Phillips, Dr and Mrs. Nolan, Mr. Hayter. Mrs. Rom, Miss Phillips, Capt. and Mrs. Duffus, Miss Langley, Dr. and Mrs. Madden, Dr. and Mrs. Milton, Mr. Potts, Mr. and Mrs. Wells, Mr. and Mrs. Satow, Mr. Roche, Mr. and Mrs. Hogg,—but the mere repetition of names, however pleasant their associations, must weary the reader and might be continued over columns. H.H. the Khedive arrived comparatively early at the tournament, followed shortly afterwards by H.RH. the Prince of Wales. H.RH. the Princess of Wales arrived later, after visiting H.H. the Khedivah and H.H. the Khedivah Mother at Koubbeh Palace in company with Lady Cromer, with whom she left Abdeen at 3.30 p.m. and proceeded by special train, leaving Pont Limoun station at 3.45 p.m. Lord Cromer arrived shortly after H.R.H the Princess of Wales had driven up. The Royal visitors were greatly pleased with all they saw of the tournament, and H.H. the Khedive was kind enough to express to the Sirdar his high appreciation of the arrange¬ments made. It was indeed one of the great events, perhaps the great event of the season.

div.head: NOTES FROM PORT SAID
div.p: NEW HARBOUR WORKS.
(FROM OUR CORRESPONDENT.)
Port Said, Saturday.

The erection of warehouses in connection with the Menzaleh Canal is nearing completion. They are being built behind Dowrie’s point and will shortly be ready to receive cargo. The Custom House and railway lines have also been started and when finished should be of great benefit to the tradespeople of the town. Messrs. Wills and Sons’ engineers have now arrived and things will 60on be in fall swing in connection with the new harbour and docks which are being built on the N. E. shore of Port Said. All the stone for the construction of the harbour and docks are to come from Suez by barges, which I understand have al¬ready been despatched from England. Murder at Ras el Ech. Some little time ago a burglary was com¬mitted at Ras el Ech and two police officers were sent from Cairo to enquire into the matter. No arrests were made, but a number of Greeks were brought up for examination. These Greeks were examined one by one, and after answering some questions one of them pulled a revolver out of his pocket, and, before any one could realise the situation, shot one of the officers in the brain, killing him on the spot. The body of the unfortunate officer was taken to Cairo accompanied by a force of 200 police from the Capital. Hotel Improvements, Messrs. Wills and Co. are making some ex¬tensive alterations to the Eastern Exchange. The shop under the hotel is, I hear, to be transformed into tea-rooms. This should prove a successful innovation. Football. The football season at Port Said has come to an end, and I think the Port Said Club have had a record year for the number of games, if not wins. Rugby and hockey have taken the place of Association to a great extent, and the young sportsmen here must feel very thankful for the presence of a guardship here again as one can always get up a match of some sort.

div.head: THE BUDGET.
div.p: FIVE MILLIONS SURPLUS.
Our London Correspondent telegraphs to-day that the Budget surplus amounts to nearly five millions sterling.

div.head: EGYPTIAN MARKETS.
div.p: FRESH DEBENTURE ISSUE.

We understand that the Egyptian Markets Company have arranged for a further issue of 5% second Debentures with a view to the construction of slaughter-houses in various centres. The amount arranged for is (gap)5 000 the whole of which has been placed with Messrs. Reid and Barnard at par, less 2% commission.

div.head: CAIRO HOTEL COMBINE.
div.p: A big English company with a capital of £500.000 is negotiating for the purchase of the National and several other hotels in Egypt. The combination will include about seven hotels right up to Khartoum.

div.head: THE SUCRERIES.
div.p: A report has been current to the effect that the Hon. A. J. Davey was about to leave Egypt to avoid the institution of legal proceed¬ings against him. We understand that, in order to dispel any erroneous impressions of this nature. Mr. Davey has abandoned his intention of leaving Egypt for the present

div.head: APPOINTMENTS.
div.p: Mr. H. Bowden-Smith, secretary to the Financial Adviser, is about to be transferred to the Public Lands Department with the rank of inspector. He will be replaced at the Ministry of Finance by Mr. Etherington Smith, who will take over Mr. Bowden-Smith’s duties in the immediate future. May we wish that the new secretary may be "Felicitor Augusto, melior Trajano.”

div.head: HIKR RIGHTS ON LAND.
div.p: From day to day the rights of hike on land grow less and less in consequence of the deci¬sions of the Mixed Appeal Court and the Wakfs General Administration that the rights could be definitely bought off on payment of a lump sum equivalent to the dues for twenty years to come. The Wakfs, for the benefit of which these hikrs had been originally created, invest the money obtained for relinquishment of •he rights in land, which is turned into Wakfs, bringing in far more than the hikrs, which required a great deal of money and trouble to collect.

div.head: BAND PERFORMANCE.
div.p: By kind permission of Lt-Col. C. J. Mark- ham and officers, the band of the 1st King’s Royal Rifles will perform the following selec¬tion of music at the Ghezireh Gymkhana on Tuesday : -

March-Weddmere-Losey Overture in the Italian Style—Schubert. Intermezzo—Bal d'Enfante—Gascone. Selection—Carmen—Bizet. Russian Dance—Pas de Patineurs—Godfrey. Valse—La Gitana—Bucalossi. Selection—The Bohemians—Puccini. Galop March—Russe—Ganne. Regimental March—Khedivial Anthem.
God Save the King.
THOMAS BROWN, Bandmaster

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: H.R H. the Prince of Wales received the President and members of the Legislative Council at Abdeen Palace at 2.30 p.m. yester¬day.

Il y a eu ausrs an petit mouvement en Natio¬nal Bank, Delta Land et Cassa Hi Sconto. La Ramleh Railway et la Delta Light sont momentanement delaissees a des cours avanta- geux. L’assemblee generale ordinaire de la Societe anonyme Brasserie des Pyramides aura lieu a Bruxelles le 2 mai prochain A l’ordre du jour : rapport du conseil; approbation des comptes de l’exercice 1905 et fixation du dividends a payer le 15 Mai 1906. Les actionnaires de la Societe Agricole et Industrielle d’Egypte sont convoques en assem- blee generale ordinaire le jeudi 3 Mai, a 4 h. p.m., au siege social au Caire. A l’ondre du jour: rapport du conseil, approbation des comptes et fixation du dividends pour l’exercise 1905, nominations statutaires, etc. Grace a l’heureuse terminaison de la conte- rence d’Algesiras, la reprise que nous avons prevne pour cette date va se produire a bref delai.

div.head: LES PUISSANCES
div.p: DEVANT LA REVOLTS ARABE. *

Tandis que 1'attention de la France et de 1’Europe etait absorbee par la guerre russo- japonaise, puis par les debuts des affaires maro- caines, un drame politique d’un interet tragique et d’une importance mondiale commencait a s'ouvrir dans la partie naturellement la plus riche, mais aussi, depuis de longs siecles, la plus abandonnee et la plus ignoree de l’Empire ottoman, l’Arabie. Longtemps opprime, et en apparence, en- dormi, le peuple arabe se reveille et revendiqne son independance. Or, qni dira, qui osera prevoir la repercus¬sion de cet etonnant mouvement sur la politi¬-que des Etats europeens, tous interesses, et la France la premiere, en sa qualite de grande puissance musulmane, a cette crise redoutable de la domination torque? Probleme pressant, d’une gravite qu’on ne peut exagerer et sur lequel il importe que l’opinion francaise soit renseignee au plus tot. Ce sera le grand bienfait du livre si informe et si sur de M. Eugene Jung que de nous mettre, par un expose lumineux et magistral de l’histoire du pays, de ses ressources economi- ques, de la revolution qui l’agite, de la situa-tion respective des puissances, en l’etat d’abor- der ce snjet. aujourd’hui presque inconnu, et qui sera demain la matiere des polemiques internationales les plus passionnees. *La Crise Mondiale de domain, par M. Eu- gene Jung, aucien Vice-Resident de Franoe en Indo-Chine.— Un volume in 16. avec one carte, broche, 3 fr. 50 (Hachette et Cie. Paris).

div.head: TO-DAY’S TELEGRAMS
div.p: AGREEMENT REACHED AT ALEGECIRAS
FRANCE’S DIPLOMATIC TRIUMPH
HOPES FOR THE FUTURE.
ALGECIRAS, March 31.
An agreement has been reached on all questions.
The Spaniards will police Tetnan and La-reche, and the French Mogador, Saffi, Mazagan, and Rabat. A mixed Franco-Spanish police force will be established at Casablanca and Tangier. (Reuter)
ALGECIRAS, March 31.
An agreement has been come to on all the questions. It will be recorded in the afternoon at the plenary sitting of the Conference. (H.)
ALGECIRAS, March 31.
The Conference has recorded a complete agreement and appointed the committee en¬trusted with the preparation of the protocol. (Havas
LONDON, April 1.

The settlement at Algeciras has been received with relief in Great Britain. Though the German object to secure one or more ports in Morocco as a footing in the Mediterranean has been thwarted, yet France’s diplomatic triumph has been tempered by her acceptance of the principle of internationalisation. On the other hand the Anglo-French entente has been thoroughly tested, and Russia’s staunchness as an ally strengthens the hope of an Anglo- Russian entente. {Reuter)
PARIS, April 1.
The French and German papers receive the entente come to at Algeciras favourably. Se-veral of them believe there will be an improve¬ment in Franco-German relations. (Havas)

div.head: TURCO-PERSIAN CONFLICT
div.p: BECOMING AGGRAVATED
CONSTANTINOPLE, April 1.

The Turco-Persian conflict is becoming aggravated, despite Sir N. O’Conor and Mr. I. A. Zinovieff’s friendly counsels to the Porte. The Turkish Ambassador at Teheran has warned the Porte regarding the postponing of concessions. (Reuter)

div.head: OUTRAGE AT SEISTAN
div.p: BRITISH CONSUL ATTACKED.
ST. PETERSBURG, March 31.
A Teheran telegram published here states that a crowd, incited by a Persian fanatic, demolished the plague hospital at Seistan and beat the British Consul and a doctor with sticks. (Reuter

div.head: EXPEDITION IN NIGERIA
div.p: COLONIAL OFFICE’S ACTION.
LONDON. March 31.

It transpires that the Colonial Office tele¬-graphed stopping the expedition against the Munshis of Benue (Nigeria) pending fuller information, and eventually permitted it to proceed, but the Sokoto outbreak mentioned on the 20th and 21st February necessitated the recall of the expedition. (Reuter)

div.head: SOUTH WEST AFRICA
div.p: GERMAN ESCORT CUT UP
BERLIN, April 1.
The Hottentots have cat up an escort of a German convoy in South-West Africa, killing an officer and 10 men and wounding 4.(Reuter)

div.head: RESCUED COURRIERES MINERS
div.p: A TERRIBLE TALE.
LENS, Maroh 31.
The rescued Courrieres miners subsisted also on decomposing horseflesh and drank water mixed with urine. They have not slept for three weeks, and are suffering from ptomaine poisoning. (Reuter)
LENS, April 1.

Minister Barthon has visited the survivors of the Courrieres catastrophe. He handed the Legion of Honour to the workmen Heny and Pauvost, whose sang-froid and energy sustained their comrades, and gold medals to the eleven others.
The Government is conferring the Legion of Honour on the chief of the German rescuers and gold medals to each of the latter. (Havas)

div.head: FINLAND.
div.p: ST. PETERSBURG, March 31. The resignation of the Governor of Finland has not been accepted. * (Reuter )

div.head: LEICESTER BYE ELECTION.
div.p: LONDON, March 31.
Leicester Bye-election. Mr. Thomasson, Li- beral, 10,766. Sir J Rolleston, Unionist, 7.208. (Reuter)

div.head: THE NATAL FIASCO
div.p: MINISTRY WITHDRAWS RESIGNATION.
LONDON, March 31.
The papers comment on the Government’s double surrender to the Labourites and Natal. (Reuter)
DURBAN, March 31.
Indignation meetings here and at Pieter-¬maritzburg yesterday were thronged. Determin¬ed resolutions were passed not to further tolerate the meddling in their domestic affairs. (Reuter)
DURBAN, March 31.

In view of the Imperial Government s assu-¬rances and at the Governor’s request, the Ministry has withdrawn its resignation and delayed the execution of the natives, which will take place on Monday. (Reuter)

div.head: REVENUE OF U K.
div.p: LONDON, April 1.
The revenue for the year ending on the 31st March amounts to £143,977,576, an increase of £607,172. The surplus amounts to £4,879,290. (Reuter)

div.head: HUGE AMERICAN STRIKE.
div.p: NEW YORK, April 1.
Half a million miners struck work yesterday. (Reuter)

div.head: CORPORATION OF WESTERN EGYPT.
div.p: Mr. T. H. Montgomery has lately been out along the line of the railway under con¬struction to the oasis and made a thorough inspection of the property of the Corporation in the Khargeh Oasis, so far as the time at his disposal permitted, making several days’ journey in the oasis itself; during these he was able also to see some of the old workings of which so many exist in the oasis.
On being asked by the representative of the “E.G.” his impression of the work done by the Corporation of Western Egypt, Mr. Mont¬gomery made the following interesting state¬ment.

"I came out at the request of a large share¬holder who wished to be satisfied that the Corporation was a thoroughly bona-fide concern and to ascertain whether the districts included in the company’s concessions were likely to prove as profitable as land in general in other parts of Egypt. I am not only satisfied that the Corporation is a thoroughly bona-fide concern but am convinced that it is already on the high road to success. The management appears 1 to me to be excellent and the results already attained appear to me to justify the expendi¬ture of capital. I am myself a farmer and land agent with considerable practical ex¬perience and I believe that the quality of the land in the Oasis which I visited is equal to that in other parts of Egypt where agriculture is carried on with large profits.

“The completion of the railway will of course be of great benefit to agriculture in the oases by increasing transport facilities. The line is being pushed on with remarkable rapidity, ‘ especially when the limited amount of plant till lately at the disposal of the company is taken into consideration, a large amount having been unavoidably delayed in transit. When the new locomotives, which arrived last week in Alexandria, have been erected and are at work on the line, progress will be vastly in-creased. As tor the quantity of work done on the line up to the present, 1 can only say that on my return after an absence of about 15 days in the oasis I was pleased to see with what rapidity and energy the embankment work and laying of the line was being pushed forward.

"As regards the area of land that can even-¬tually be brought under cultivation, I cannot at present indulge in detailed forecasts with any pretence to accuracy, but my observations of the large areas formerly under cultivation that are in the company's possession together with the large tracts of virgin soil on which wells are now being bored embolden me to say that these tracts can only be described as vast and their soil as of a high quality.

"The crops on the land now being cultivated by the Corporation or by natives struck me as being equal to anything that I have seen in other parts of Egypt. The Corporation has already a considerable area under cultivation, and this area increases as every new well is brought into operation. The natives are certainly ready to purchase land in the oases. From enquiries that I made I found that buyers were numerous, and I am informed that applications for several thousand feddans have been receiv¬ed by the company. The wells already bored yield a very good supply of water, e g.—the last sunk is giving 250 gallons a minute without in any way affecting the flow of the other wells in the vicinity. As a general rule a flow of 100 gallons per minute is sufficient for the irrigation of 30 feddans of land and from all the evidence before me I feel certain that not only was a much larger area than at present brought under cultivation in Roman times by the aid of wells but that all that has been since lost to cultivation can be reclaimed by a proper system of well irrigation, or in many oases by simply clearing out the old wells.

"As for minerals I saw many evidences of old workings in four or five different localities in the oasis, which must at one time have had an enormous yield and I am aware that the Corporation geologists reported favourably on the continuance of the yield.
“In fact the prospects are excellent and I am confident that within a little time the Corpora-tion will have opened up a new and rich pro¬-vince of Egypt.
“I should like to add that when I made known the object of my visit to Egypt to the Corpora-¬tion’s officials I was afforded every facility for investigating its affairs in the very fullest manner.”

div.head: AVIS
div.p: L’Assemblee Generale tenue le 27 Mars 1906 n’ayant pas reuni le nombre d’actions requis pour approuver la modification pro¬-posee aux Statuts, Messieurs les Actionnaires sont conveques a nouveau en Assemblee Gene-rale Extraordinaire pour le mardi 17 Avril 1906 a 4 heures de l’apres-midi, au Siege Social dans les Bureaux de Messierus Russell, Kerr and Wyat, Maison Chawarbi Pacha, rue Kasr el Nil, au Caire.
Dans cette nouvelle reunion la resolution ci-aures deviendra definitive si l’assemblee se compose au moins de la moitie da Capital Social.
ORDRE DU JOUR.
Approbation de la Resolution ci-apres, votee provisoirement par l’Assemblee Generale du 17 Mars 1906.
RESOLUTION.

Le Capital Social est porte a £ 150 000 par l’emission de 10,000 nouvelles actions ordi- naires de £5 chacune. Ces Actions seront emises au pair. Les souscripteurs payeront en outre dix shellings par action, representant les Coupons Nos. 1 et 2, attaches aux nouvelles actions, de facon a ce que ces actions aient les memes droits que celles deja existantes. La somme de £ 5.000, montant des dits coupons sera portee a an compte special.
Ea consequence, les Articles 5 et 6 des Statuts sont rediges comme suit:
ART. 5.
Le Capital Social est fixe a cent cinquante mille Livres Sterling.
ART. 6.
Le Capital est represente par trente mille actions ordinaires de cinq livres Sterling cha-cune.
Il est en outre cree huit mille actions de dividende, sans designatio de valeur.

Deux mille actions ordinaires entierement liberees et six mille actions de dividende sout reservees a la remuneration des apports speci¬-fies a l’Acte Preliminaire auquel les presents Statuts sont annexes.
Toutes actions creees en augmentation du Capital Social ne pourront etre emises au- dessus du pair. Si elles sont emises au-dessus du pair, 1’excedent sera mis a la reserve.
Il ne pourra jamais etre cree de nouvelles actions de dividende.

Tout Actionnaire a le droit d’assister a l’Assemblee Generale a condition de deposer ses actions quatre jours avant l’Assemblee soit an plus tard le 12 avril 1906 dans l’un des eta-blissements ci-apres designes, cu il lui sera delivre une carte d’admission.

Au Siege Social au Caire, dans les Bureaux de Messieurs Russell, Kerr & Wyatt a la National Bank of Egypt, a l’Anglo-Egyptian Bank Limited—a la Bank of Egypt Ltd., au Credit Lyonnais, a la Banque Imperiale Otto-mane, au Caire ou a Alexandria.
Les dits etablissements remattront sur de¬mands des formules de procuration aux Action-naires qui desireraient se faire representer par un antre actionnaire (Art. 25 des Statuts).

div.head: REMARKS.
div.p: We have been treated lately to unequal weather for this time of year. Yesterday was very windy, and the clouds of dust which were blown about made it unpleasant for pedestrians. div.head: PAPYRUS EXCAVATIONS.
div.p: DR. GRENFELL’S LECTURE.

Last week, at the Continental Hotel, Dr. Grenfell gave a most interesting lecture on the excavations for papyrus conducted by Dr. Hunt and himself daring the last eleven years. He began by showing how completely the introduction of Greek as the official language of Egypt changed the relations of the country with the rest of the civilised world. Under the rule of the Pharaohs Egypt with its difficult and peculiar language and system of writing showed a long-drawn Oriental despotism stand-ing in splendid isolation : it has influenced succeeding civilisations neither in art, literature nor religion. After the conquest of the country by Alexander the Great, Greek became the official and social language and remained so for a thousand years. Egypt became the meet¬ing-ground of East and West and its influence during that period on Hellenic literature, Roman laws and Christian religion was pro- found. All the social and administrative ma-¬chinery of this time is known with a minuteness which is lacking in any other epoch of ancient history, thanks to the vast masses of papyri which have been preserved by the dryness of the soil. Hence the excavations of Drs. Grenfell and Hunt are of unique interest and import¬ance, for not only do they supply us with valuable evidence, but they are rescuing pre¬cious documents which would otherwise be destroyed by the fellaheen in the sebbakh digging. The appalling and wanton destruction of ancient monuments throughout the country is one of the saddest features of modern Egypt. All the more therefore should lovers of art or literature assist excavators to rescue these doomed treasures. It is often said that the Egypt of to-day is much the same in essentials, at any rate in the country, as the Egypt under the Pha¬raohs : but if an Egyptian of the time of Rameses were revived to-day he would probably scarce- cely recognise the country. The Nile and the Pyramids would still be there and the peasants still work shadoofs and till the fields : but many striking features of modern life, such as money and camels, would be strange to him and the whole social and political organisation would be different. If, on the other hand, a native of the Ptolemaic period were suddenly to become alive again he would at once find himself in a familiar atmosphere. The vast and minutely organised bureaucracy with its passion for endless ac- counts, the system of banks, and even something like the Bourse, the foreign con¬trollers of Departments with Moudirs and Omdehs, the latter of whom might be Greek but were often native, especially in later times. Probably there are other organisations in the world as complete and minute as the Egyptian but no other country is so zealous in committing all its deeds to writing. This though doubtless trying to the inha¬bitants has made it possible to reconstruct the life of the period. There was also an excellent postal service, but for letters of State only, for the idea that private letters should be entrusted to the State is a modern and not an ancient idea. Many letters, both public and private, including invitations to dinner (always for the following day) have been recovered.

In some ways the Alexandrine might think the present state of the country inferior to that of his own day, especially in educa¬tion and athletic sports. The efforts of the English however in both these subjects night recall the vivifying influence of the Ptole¬mies. Dr. Grenfell then gave an interesting account of the papyrus plant and of the preparation of the writing material. He then went on to describe the delicate and difficult task of finding the papyrus writings in the ground or in mummy cases and of removing them as far as possible intact. He also gave a short sketch of his labours with Dr Hunt during the last 12 years in the Fayoum, and at Oxyrrhyncos which was during the later Roman time the second city of the province, racking in size, population and importance after only Alexandria. In Christian times there were great numbers of monks and nuns, at one period ten and twelve thousand of each in the neighbourhood. At present even the ruins of the town have been destroyed for building material and only the vast rubbish-heaps are left to mark the site. The lecture concluded with a series of photographs illustrating the site, the methods of digging and specimens of finds. The latter can be divided into literary fragments and official and private papers. The literary fragments are partly theological, including the famous sayings of Jesus, and partly classical, includ- ing some fragments of Homer written before the great edition of Aristarchus and a thou¬sand years earlier than our oldest manuscript. It is pleasant to be able to add that Drs. Grenfell and Hunt have had such a success¬ful season and so much more remains than was expected that another year will be ne¬cessary to complete the excavations.

div.head: SPORT AND PLAY.
div.p: MENA HOUSE GYMKHANA.

The Gymkhanas which are held from time to time at Mena House Hotel at the race-course are invariably characterized by amusing sport and a fashionable attendance. Favoured with excellent weather, last Friday’s meeting proved most enjoyable, and in spite of the attraction held out by the visit of the Prince and Princess of Wales, a great many visitors and residents went out daring the forenoon and lunched at Mena House Hotel.

The celebrated chef of Mena House Hotel, as usual, produced an excellent luncheon. and all who sat down in the picturesque dining hall greatly appreciated his efforts. Mr. George Royle had a party, as also Mr. Sloman and Mrs. Rottenburg, besides many others.

Racing commenced at 3 p.m. sharp and all the events were got through with admirable promptitude. Mr. Collan Fox kindly acted as starter, Mr. Mason and Dr. Wakeling as judges, and Mr. Weckel as clerk of the course. The following were the results :—
Donkey race for Gentlemen.—12 started. Capt. Mackenzie, 1st; Mr. Goodchild, 2nd.
Hand-in-hand Race for Ladies and Gents on Donkeys : each pair had to hold oppo¬-site ribbon. 14 started. Winners : Miss Nelly Farrar and Mr. Morris.
Throwing Tennis Balls on Horses.—5 start¬ed. 1st, Mr. Atterbury ; 2nd, Mr. Dickinson.
Ladies’ Donkey Race. Distance 300 yards, 12 started. 1st, Mrs. Stubbs ; 2nd, Miss H. Farrar.

Ladies’ Nomination Race on horses. This was by far the most interesting race of the programme. Competitors had to light a cigar, get into costume assisted by ladies, open umbrella, mount a horse, ride round post 300 yards and home. Some excellent costumes had been provided by the management of Mena House Hotel and drivers were cheered with great enthusiasm. Mr. Moberley was first and Mr. Dickenson was rewarded for having the best costume.
Ladies’ Scurry (2 furlongs) —8 ladies start¬ed, Miss Nelly Farrar on Dr. Wakeling’s—was first, and Mrs. Loose on Mr. Weckel’s Prince 2nd.
Open Donkey Race for ladies and gentle¬men. — 16 started. Miss Nelly Farrar, 1st; Mr. Goodchild 2nd.

Thread-and-needle Race on ponies. This last event produced some very good racing. The field went away in a bunch, but Mr. Atter- bury and Miss Rottenburg were easy winners, Mr. Atterbury passing before the judge's box before the others had reached the post.
The proceedings closed by 5.30 p.m. and the presentation of prizes took place on the terrace of Mena House Hotel by Mr. Weckel’s little eldest daughter, Lucy.

div.head: CORRESPONDANCE
div.p: Nous ne sommes pas responsables des opinions emises parnos correspondants, mais nous desirons, dans un esprit de loyale polemique, permettre- dans certaines limites neces saires- une libre discussion.
LE CANAL MAHMOUDIEH.
Monsieur le Directeur
de "l’Egyptian. Gazette”

Un journal de notre villa vient d’exposer dans ses grandes lignes, un projet qui serait a l’etude par le Gouvernement pour le changement du cours du Canal Mahmoudieh depuis le Jardin Nouzha en lui creant un second bras de deri-vation aboutissant a la mer pres de l’Abattoir. L’article se termine en faisant appel au con¬cours du commerce d’Exportation et d’lmporta- tion, aux Chambres de Commerce et a la Muni¬cipality. Nous ne voyons pas bien pourquoi cet appel, du moment que l’expose da projet tel qu’il est presente, montre une idee bien arretee quant a son trace et a son but.
Examinons rapidement si vraiment la gran-deurd’ Alexandrie necessite pourl’accroissement du trafic par voie fluviale, l’execution de oe projet.

Le canal Mahmoudieh, dit-on, est insuffi- sant; de plus, il gene la circulation, il coupe le port et le quartier des chounahs en deux. C’est exact, mais a-t-on songe a remedier a catte situation d’une facon quelconque ? Non. Maintenant, brusquement on veut deplacer le centre du mouvement fluvial et le reporter, disons le mot, au diable. Combien de ports n’envieraient-ils pas la situation privilegiee de celui d’Alexandrie qui possede le debouche de sa voie fluviale en plein port, a cote precise-ment de sa grande gare de marchandises. Si l’on va transporter les excluses dans la rade, fort mal protegee contre les vents du Nord-Ouest par le grand brise-lames, il y aura certainement des journees entieres en plein hiver ou l’acces des ecluses sera, sinon impossible, da moins dangereax. De plus, quel enorme detour les chalands, mahonnes, alleges, etc. ne vont-ils pas devoir faire pour aller du bout du port actuel jasqu’aux ecluses ? Actuellement le canal est justement a egale distance des installations anciennes et nou- velles du port, dono i’ideal.

Quel spectacle serait en hiver celui de- barques arabes ou des mahonnes chargees de charbons et de chalands a fond plat se tre- moussant sur les ecluses de la rade pour atteindre les ecluses, et doublant le bout du mole aux charbons!
Poor s’en faire une idee il n’y a qu’a voir comme un tache de faciliter l’acces de la nouvelle cale seche pres du semaphore, se- approches etant dangereuses par tous les temps.

D’un sutre cote, a-t-on bien examine la nature des terrains que le nonveau bras du canal va traverser 1 L’exteosion actuelle de la gare de Gabbary nous indique que le canal suivra le remblai du chemin de fer reliant Hadra a Gabbary, coupera la ligne Gabbary Mellaha, et suivra jusqu’a la bifurcation de Gabel Zeitoun un lit artificiel qu’il faudra en- trement etablir dans les vases da Mariout. Plus loin, le canal devra couper la ligne des carrieres du Mex. et s’engager dans les ter¬-rains sablonneux qui se rencontrent depuis le Gabbary jusqu’au Mex, et ou l’on trouve l’eau de mer chaque fois que l’on creuse un trou profond de deux metres. Il faudra donc etablir le lit du canal avec son plafond presque au niveau du sol actuel. Ce sera un beau travail qui fera honneur a la science des hydraulioiens, mais qui cotera enormement.

L’article dont il est question plus haut, parle aussi de ne plus utiliser les ecluses du Mahmoudieh actuel, de diminuer son debit, de ne plus ouvrir les ponts tournants actaels. Mais alors autant le supprimer definitivement et completer d’un coup la ruine des proprietaires de chounahs de tout le quartier de Minet el- Bassal.
Quel va etre le premier resultat da projet qui vient d’etre annonce au public ? une course au clocher pour les terrains du Mex, et une speculation monstre de ce cote-la.

Il nous semble qu’il aurait ete bien plus rationnel, ne fut-ce que comme mesure transi- toire, de porter au maximum la capacite d’uti- lisation du Mahmoudieh actuel, et nous allons indiquer comment: ce n’est pas tant l’augmen-tation du nombre de ponts qui est necessaire que l’elargissement dans de fortes proportions de tous les ponts actuels, car ou pourra placer ou 1’on voudra de nouveaux ponts, s’lla n aboutissent pas de chaque cote a de grandes arteres, ils seront plutot un obstacle qu’une facilite, et dans la topographie presente de ce quartier de Minet el Bassal, les arteres devant aboutir aux ponts projetes, n’existent pas. De plus, une reglementation severe des heures d’ouverture des ponts doit etre appliquee; qu’on les ouvre davantage la nuit, et moins le jour. Rien de plus ridicule dernierement que l’ouverture du Pont Zulficar precisement au moment ou la gare de Gabbary allait fermer, et ou la cohue des charrettes etait a son comble. Qo’on songe aussi a munir les ponts de meca-nismes electroques on permettant l’ouverture et la fermeture rapide et non de mecanismes a la main datant de 1830. Voila deja une cause du peu d’emploi utile da canal actuel.

Quant an Chemin de fer, que l’on mette donc a execution le grand pont tournant projete de- vaut les ecluses du port du bout du quai E. au quai F. De cette facon, les ecluses pourront ouvrir quand on vondra, puisqu’on aura un autre pont independent des ecluses pour che-min de fer, pietons et voitures.

Enfin, parlons de l’utilisation actuelle des rives du Mahmoudieh. Elle est ridicule. Com-¬ment n’a-t-on pas encore songe a abaisser ces enormes murs du quai entre le pont Vieux et le pont Zulficar. Si l’on depensait ait de ce cote- la 100,00 £ pour remanier la topographie de la ville, ce serait de l’argent bien place. Pour, quoi entre le pont des ecluses et le pont vieux laisse-ton sobsister ce petit jardin au lieu d’e- largir d’autaut le canal ?

Tout le quai du cote de la ville entre le pont vieux et le pont des tramways est inutilise; que de place perdue ! il y a la de quoi faire au niveau du canal, un vaste quai avec des rampec douces; le meme travail pourrait se faire pour tout le coude du canal jusqu’au Pont Zulficar.

La ville et le Gouvernement devraient ex. proprier les deux rives du canal sur vingt metres de largeur, de cheque cote pour abaisser les rives faire des routes convenables et surtout rendre ainsi au canal la veritable largeur qu’il a possedee jadis. On peut dire qu’actuellement plus de 5o % de l’espace entre les ecluses et l’usine des tramways est perdu inutilement.

De plus, on devrait surveiller davantage le sejour et l’accostage des barques sur tout ce parcours, et se montrer tout aussi severe qu’en Europe. Que l’on se decide donc a reglementer la navigation fluviale. Quant aux compagnies flaviales, pourquoi ne pas creer pour elles un emplacement special pour degager le canal Un bassin special semble tont indique et pourrait etre etabli a peu de frais. L’endroit existe: o’est la vaste depression de terrain en face de 1’Usine des Tramways, entre le canal et le reu blai du chemin de fer; on pourrait faire la un splendide basin pour les chalands des com-pagnies de Navigation et cela a peu de frais, pui-que le sol est deja en contrebas du Canal. Pourquoi ne pas creer comme dans les grands ports d’Europe, des bassins pour la batellerie ? Pourquoi, au lieu de cela, chercher a l’echelonner sur un canal, le long de ses rives. L’angle du canal pres du pont des Tramways ou se trouve le poste des Pompieres est deja un vrai basin bien mal utilize, car il est plein de vase, et on l’a a moitie remblaye pour y erablir un depot.

Vraiment on se demande pourquoi l’on ne chercherait pas d’abord a tirer profit du canal actuel avant d’aller creuser un nouveau canal qui ne pourra reussir que si l’on comble celui-ci, car tant que le Mahmoudieh existers, il y a beaucoup a parier qu-il aura toujours la pre-ference du commerce, meme si on le laisse dans son etat actuel.
Il y a lieu d’esperer que les Associations du Commerce d’Importation et d’Exportation ainsi que les Chambres de Commerce etudieront la question et sauront intervener en temps utile.
Agreez, Monsieur, mes salutations etc.
A.D.
Alexandrie, le 31 Mars

div.head: Circulaire H. De Vries et Boutigny
div.p: NOTES ET CRITIQUES
Le Caire, 31 Mare.
Le taux de l’escompte a Londres vient d’etre encore reduit de 1/8 a 3 1/4.
Au Stock Exchange, le Consolide anglais a reagi hier de 1/8 a 90 1/2. L’Unifiee, la National Bank, l'Agricole et la Daira sont restees invariees.
A Paris l’action Credit Foncier Egyptien, est renseiguee en hausse de 4 francs a 795.

Notre marche des valeurs a ete, ce matin, tres anime et en excellente tendance, surtout au debut de la seance. Les transactions prati- quees ont ete nombreuses sur quelques titres, specialement en National Hotels, qui ont eu les honneurs de la matinee.
La National Bank s’est maintenue a ses prix d’hier. L’Agricole s’est inscrite a 10 3/32 pour cloturer a 10 1/16. Le Comptoir Financier a progresse a 7 1/8.

L’action Credit Foncier s’est raffermie a 796. La part de fondateur Immobiliere a avance a 645 et celle de l’Agricole du Nil a 9 3/8. L’action Entreprises Immobilizes et Travaux a ete cotee 4 1/16 et la part de fouda-¬teur L. E. 15 1/2.
Dans le groupe des Hotels, les Nungovich out cloture a 18 5/8, les Baehler a 5 7/8 et les Upper Egypt a 5 5/16. L’Anglo-American a avance a 6 6/16.

Grand mouvement, comme nous venons de le dire, sur les actions National Hotels, qui ont atteint 4 3/4 pour cloturer a 4 11/16. Largement traitees, les parts de fondateur ont saute, par bonds successifs, de 100 a 135 pour revenir a 120 et colturer a 125.
Parmi les petites valeurs, les Delta Land ont monte a 3 11/16 pour finir a 3 1/2. La part de fondateur Estates s’est inscrite a 13 1/4- Les Abdy ont cloture a 1 1/2 et les Glymenopoulo a 1 9/16.

Par une lettre en date d’hier, la direction da National Hotel nous informe qu'use puis-sante Compagnie anglaise, au capital de £ 500,000, est en train d’acheter cet Hotel, ainsi que six a sept autres en Egypte pour former une grande Societe hoteliere.
La lettre ajoute que l’affaire est presque conclue.

L'assemblee generale extraordinaire de la Compagnie Agricole du Nil, dont nous avons parle dans notre Circulaire du 27 Mars, sera tenue au siege social a Anvers le 21 avril prochain. Il s’agit, comme nous l’avions dit, d’une augmentation du capital social, neces- sitee par le developpement florissant des affai¬-res de la Societe.

Ajoutons a ce propos que la Compagnie, qui avait entrepris la reveute par petits lots d’une propreiete de 18 feddans envirou, acquise par elle il y a quelques mois sur le canal Ismailieh a Mahmacha, vient de liquider cette operation.

Partage en 140 lots environ, ce terrain, convoite aurtout par une categorie de petits rentiers, a ete l’objet de ventes continues qui, par progressions successives dans les prix. ont permis a la Societe de realiser au benefice moyen de 100 % environ sur le prix d’achat.
C’est un resultat qui meritait d’etre signale au double point de vue de l'intelligente gestion de la Compagnie et de la qualite des acque-reurs des lots.

Ainsi qae nous l’avons annonce dans notre Circulaire d’avant-hier, la Brasserie des Pyra-mides vient de vendre, au prix de P.E. 71 le metre carre, son domaine disponsible de Ghizeh. Il a’agit d’une superficie de pres de 63,000 metres, ce qui fait une somme d’environ L.E. 45,000.

Pour donner une idee exacte de l’importance de la transaction, il faut rappeler que la capital actions de la Societe est actuellement de Frs. 2,000,000 et le capital obligations de Frs. 850,000. Cette vente represente donc le 40 % du capital global. Desormais la machinerie peut figurer pour rien au bilan.

D’autre part, il reste a la Societe les 29,000 metres de l’Usine qui peuvent, a bon droit, etres portes dans les comptes su prix de vente actuel, ce qui constute une autre reserve pour de futurs developpements. Il faut encore eiterm a tutre de memoire, le droit de jouissance que la Societe possede pendant 27 ans encore, aur 63,000 metres du domaine du Wakf, ce qui contitue une reserve supplementaire.

En attendant, le montant de la vente du domaine disponsible permettra a la Societe de rembourses toutes ses obligations et de dispo-ser d’une reserve de Frs. 25,000 environ, deduction faite du courtage et des frais.
Ces resultats remarquables font vraiment honneur a la gestion de Chakour pacha et de ses collegues du conseil d’administration.
Nous detachons d’une de nos correspond-dances d’Alexandrie, en date d’hier soir, les lignes suivantes:

“On prevoit un movement de hausse aur les actions de la Port-Said Salt Association. Le projet de fus on avec la salt and Soda a ete, parait-il mis de cote par auite du droit acquis par la Port Said de vendre dans toute l’Egypte le sel provenant de ses salines. Ce droit serait confirme par une lettre de l’etat reclamant a la Societe la redevance sur les ventese effectuees depuis le ler janvier.”
Les cours du coton sont signales en reprise en Amerique. Hier, le Mai a gagne 12 points at l’Octobre 11. Le disponsible est reste invarie.
Les arrivages a New York ont ete de 13,000 balles contre 45,000.
Les marche de Liverpool est en petit reac-tion.
Ici, le Mai, qui a fini tres ferme hier soi a 20 25/32 sur de bonnes veutes a Liverpool, a ouvert ce matin a 20 7/8 pour cloture a 21 1/32.

div.head: THEATRE ZIZINIA
div.p: “ ASRA EL "
Cet opera, qui avait ete deja donne ici il y a quelques annees, vient d’etre repris avec un certain success.
Grace a une execution soignee et a l’excel-lences des interpretes, l’ceuvre, bien qu’un peu profunde, commence a etre goutee du public.
Le compositeur se sert tres ingenieusement des procedes wagneriens sans cependant en abuser. Les leitmotiv sont assez nombreux et obtiennent chez lui leur plein epanouissement.

La melodie, bien qu’assez riche, mauque un peu de soufflé et dechaleur. Elle ne transportera pas le gros du public. L’oeuvre ne sera appre-ciee a sa juste valeur que par les quelques inities qui en admireront la conception et la technique dans la forme.
L’orchestration, bien qu’un peu bruyante n’est guere compliquee.
Mmes Lavin et Russ out ete remarquables. Longobardi dans Asrael a ete bon.

div.head: LA COMPAGNIE IMMOBILIERE.
div.p: La 'Bourse Egyptienne” attire l’attention sur une champagne tendaucieuse menee par quelques journaux financiers belgas contre l’avenir des operations foncieres en Egypte en genereal et contre la Compaguie Immobiliere en particulier.

D’apres eux, d’Egypte verrait bientut a’ar-reter le bel elan daus lequel elle est actuelle-ment engage, et l’Immobiliere don’t la situa-tion florissante ne serait qu’un effet de mirage, serait menaces de prochaine, etc. etc.

La “Bourse” fait remarquer que ces predict-tions sinistres, ou plutot amussantes, suivent a quelque temps, l’arrivee d’un paquet de titres de l’Immobiliere. Or, on se demande si ce n’est pas la l’effet d’un retour de detenteurs qui, confus et repentants d’avoir realize a des condi-tions peu avantageuses, essasient de se rattraper en faissant tomber les cours pour ramasser les-titres a bon marche.

div.head: SEMOULERIE PERFECTIONNEE
div.p: “LE LYS”

J’ai l’honneur d’informer le public et plus specialement ma respectable clientele que, tout eo gardant mon Moulin a farines de Tarsous (Turquie d’Asie), fonde en 1890, je viens d’ins-taller a Alexandrie une semoulerie de tout dernier modele functionnant d’apres les aya-temes perfectionnes les plus recents de France et de Suisse. Grace a ma lougue experience dans ce genre d’industrie ainsi qu’aux moyens exceptionnels don’t je dispose pour m’appro-visionner en bles de tout premier choix an Syrie, daus le Levant et en Russie, j’espere pouvoir donner pleiue et entire satisfaction sous tous les rapports.
Dans l’espoir que vous voudrez bien me con-server votre pratique et faire l’essai du produit de ma nouvelle usine,
Agreez etc.
GABRIEL MARINO.
Mon bureau se trouve a cote de la Poste de Ras-el-Tin.—Telephone N° 17-68—et la fabri-que daus le meme quartier, Rue Gouda.
P.S.— On peut se procurer daus le meme etablissement du son, des criblures et de la farine. 27600-15A-1

Coton.—La fermete s'est accentuees tout d'un coup et la cloture a ete active et en hausre. La speculation semble decidee, plus que jamais, a pousser les cours. Le novembre aussi a ete entraine et pas mal d'affaires ont eie traitees a 16 3/4.
Graines de coton.—Fermes, mais plutot negligees, l'attention genereale etant absorbee par le coton.
Fèves.—Cours toujours nominaux.
